awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: New Constraints on the Geodynamics of the Lake Bonneville Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
The significance of this project is based, in part, on the rarity of this type of opportunity in geodynamic research. Lake Bonneville was one of the largest pluvial lakes on the planet during the late Pleistocene, has one of the best known lake-level histories, possesses multiple shorelines of known ages, and is now covered by the best topographic data set for any pluvial lake basin of comparable size. The convergence of these factors, as well as advances in modeling and analysis, will facilitate greater understanding of the processes and rates of isostatic rebound and accompanying crustal deformation. This study will provide a template for what is possible for geodynamic studies in lacustrine basins located in other regions and on other continents.  In addition to developing new insights on the geodynamics of the Bonneville basin that will be used by geophysicists and others to better constrain viscosity models and understand the earthquake cycle, the results of this research have implications for other disciplines such as geochronology. Results from this work may also assist in geothermal energy exploration by better constraining the dimensions of high heat flow anomalies, which may be expressed by regions of super-elevated shorelines not consistent with their loading history. This project will also result in the interdisciplinary training of graduate students and be highlighted and disseminated to a broad audience through the Great Basin Paleoenvironmental Database website (www.dri.edu/gbped). In addition to adding to this database with new publications resulting from the research, the project will develop an online educational module highlighting the Bonneville basin's well documented environmental and geodynamic history. This module will be part of a larger effort to educate interested viewers on various aspects of the Quaternary history of the Great Basin.

The Lake Bonneville basin has become one of the premier examples of geodynamic research since the isostasy model of an elastic plate overlying a visco-elastic substrate was introduced in 1890. Since that time, the basin has been the subject of numerous studies elaborating on the timing, magnitude, and processes of isostatic rebound and the response of the crust and upper mantle to the enormous loads imposed by Lake Bonneville. The goal of this project is to employ much higher density shoreline elevation measurements, a more refined loading history, geographic information system spatial analysis of the rebound signal, and a fully three-dimensional finite-element model for simulating the isostatic response of the Earth. Since the last major publication on the rebound of the basin, significant improvements have been made to the lake-level chronology (loading history), modeling sophistication, three-dimensional analysis, topographic data, and the ability to define the geometry of rebound recorded by multiple, discrete shorelines. The combination of these improvements will lead to a much better constrained three-dimensional Earth model documenting lateral variations in lithospheric strength and viscosity structure. Geochronology results from the work may provide constraints on rates of shoreline development and also may lead to revision of calibrated production rates for cosmogenic surface exposure dating.

por.por_cntn:
During the last ice ages, about 30,000 to 15,000 years ago, large lakes and ice sheets accumulated on the continents and caused substantial subsidence beneath them because of their enormous weight, in many cases by many tens of meters. When the lakes desiccated and ice sheets melted, the parts of the Earth that were subject to these loads responded in an equal but opposite sense in a process referred to as isostatic rebound. One of the premier natural laboratory to perform isostatic rebound or geodynamic research is in the Lake Bonneville basin of Utah and adjacent parts of Nevada and Idaho.

Pleistocene Lake Bonneville grew to be the largest lake in western North America by about 18,000 years ago, covering about 52,000 km2 and containing about 10,400 km3 of water at its highstand. Eventually the rising lake found an outlet and began draining toward the Pacific Ocean. The shoreline that formed while the lake was spilling is called the Bonneville shoreline, which is the highest shoreline in the basin. At some point the natural dam that was holding back the lake failed and about half of the water in the lake rapidly flowed through the outlet, resulting in the Bonneville flood. After the flood the lake continued to spill through the outlet, now about 125 m lower, for up to a couple thousand years. The shoreline graded to this sill is known as the Provo shoreline.

The enormous weight of Lake Bonneville caused the Earth?s crust to subside and the upper mantle material to be displaced from beneath the basin. As the lake evaporated at the end of the Pleistocene, the water load was reduced and the Earth isostatically rebounded. We can determine the magnitude and geometry of this deformation by measuring the elevations of preserved shorelines that originally formed in a horizontal manner.

When the Bonneville shoreline formed about 18,000 years ago, it was essentially horizontal even though the load of the lake had substantially depressed the crust of the Earth by that time. Imagine that you were in a boat on Lake Bonneville during the late Pleistocene. You could sail from one end of the lake to the other, passing many beaches on islands and peninsulas along the way, but essentially staying at the same elevation throughout your journey. If you now went back to those same beaches, they are substantially different in elevation but vary in predictable ways.

One of the goals of this research was to characterize the geometry of isostatic rebound in the Bonneville basin at two different times by measuring the elevations of the Bonneville and Provo shorelines at multiple locations. To this end, we collected 530 measurements on the Bonneville shoreline and 199 measurements on the Provo shoreline. Although the Bonneville shoreline formed as a horizontal surface, shorelines in the middle of the basin are about 75 m higher than the same age shorelines on the margins of the basin, reflecting the magnitude and geometry of isostatic rebound in this basin (Figure 1). Similarly, the Provo shoreline reflects about 50 m of deformation, a smaller amount because the Provo lake was smaller.

We are using the shoreline elevation measurements as input into a geodynamic model that provides estimates of the crustal rigidity beneath the basin and the viscosity of the upper mantle. The time-varying load of the lake is also input into the model in the form of a lake-level curve, which specifies how large the load was and how it varied through time. The results of this model is important for understanding crustal phenomena such as how stress is built up and released during an earthquake cycle.

We are currently analyzing our data to look for anomalies in the rebound patterns that may reflect lateral variations in crustal and mantle properties. We are also examining the data to determine if the isostatic subsidence and rebound that has occurred in this basin has had any geomorphic effects, such as shifting the paths of rivers flowing toward the basin center or causing abnormally thick accumulations of beach gravel. If either of these are true, it would point to complex linkages between the atmosphere, deep Earth processes, and processes occurring on the surface of the Earth, providing a more interesting and complete picture of our dynamic Earth.
